member.name: M:Elastic.Apm.Agent.AddFilter(System.Func{Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction,Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction})
member.summary: Adds a filter which gets called before each transaction gets sent to APM Server. In the , you have access to the instance which gets sent to APM Server and you can modify it. With the return value of the , you can also control if the should be sent to the server or not. If the returns a non-null instance then it will be sent to the APM Server, and if it returns null, the event will be dropped and won't be sent to the APM server.
member.param: The filter that can process the and decide if it should be sent to APM Server or not.
member.returns: true if the filter was added successfully, false otherwise. In case the method returns false the filter won't be called.

member.name: T:Elastic.Apm.Api.Destination.Optional`1
member.summary: The goal is to allow public API user to prohibit automatic deduction of any of `context.destination` properties. To achieve that we need a way to distinguish between `null` as the initial value (meaning public API user is okay with us automatically deducing it) and `null` explicitly set via public API (meaning the user doesn't want us to automatically deduce it).

member.name: T:Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction
member.summary: A transaction describes an event captured by the APM agent instrumentation. They are a special kind of Span that have additional attributes associated with them.
member.remarks: This interface is the public contract for a transaction. It is not intended to be used by a consumer of the agent to provide different transaction implementations.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction.Context
member.summary: Any arbitrary contextual information regarding the event, captured by the agent, optionally provided by the user. This field is lazily initialized, you don't have to assign a value to it and you don't have to null check it either.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction.Custom
member.summary: An arbitrary mapping of additional metadata to store with the event. Custom is used to add non-indexed, custom contextual information to transactions. Non-indexed means the data is not searchable or aggregatable in Elasticsearch, and you cannot build dashboards on top of the data. However, non-indexed information is useful for other reasons, like providing contextual information to help you quickly debug performance issues or errors. Unlike the data in this property is not trimmed.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction.Result
member.summary: A string describing the result of the transaction. This is typically the HTTP status code, or e.g. "success" for a background task.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction.SpanCount
member.summary: The total number of correlated spans, including started and dropped

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction.Type
member.summary: The type of the transaction. Example: 'request'

member.name: M:Elastic.Apm.Api.ITransaction.EnsureParentId
member.summary: If the transaction does not have a ParentId yet, calling this method generates a new ID, sets it as the ParentId of this transaction, and returns it as a . If there is already a ParentId, the method just returns the existing ParentId. This enables the correlation of the spans the JavaScript Real User Monitoring (RUM) agent creates for the initial page load with the transaction of the backend service.
member.returns: The generated that was applied to the current transaction, or the existing one.

To dynamically change agent operation, use

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.ExcludedNamespaces

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.FlushInterval
member.summary:
The maximal amount of time (in seconds) events are held in queue until there is enough to send a batch. It's possible for a batch to contain less then events if there are events that need to be sent out because they were held for too long. A lower value will increase the load on your APM server, while a higher value can increase the memory pressure on your app. A higher value also impacts the time until transactions are indexed and searchable in Elasticsearch.
Positive number - The maximal amount of time to hold events in queue.
0 - Events are not held in queue but are sent immediately.
Negative - Invalid and the default value is used instead.
Default value:

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.HostName
member.summary: Allows for the reported hostname to be manually specified. If unset, the hostname will be detected.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.LogLevel
member.summary: The logging level for the agent.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.MaxBatchEventCount
member.summary:
The maximal number of events to send in a batch. It's possible for a batch contain less then the maximum events if there are events that need to be sent out because they were held for too long.
Positive number - The maximal number of of events to send in a batch.
0 and negative - Invalid and the default value is used instead.
Default value: Also see: and

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.MaxQueueEventCount
member.summary:
The maximal number of events to hold in queue as candidates to be sent. If the queue is at its maximum capacity then the agent discards the new events until the queue has free space.
Positive number - The maximal number of of events to send in a batch. If MaxQueueEventCount is less than then is used as MaxQueueEventCount.
0 and negative - Invalid and the default value is used instead.
Default value:

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.Recording
member.summary: Whether the agent is recording. When set to true. the agent instruments and capture requests, tracks errors, and collects and sends metrics. When set to false, the agent does not collect data or communicate with the APM server, except to fetch central configuration. Recording can be changed during the lifetime of the application.
member.remarks: As this is a reversible switch, agent threads are not terminated when inactivated, but they will be mostly idle in this state, so the overhead should be negligible.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.SanitizeFieldNames
member.summary: Sometimes it is necessary to sanitize the data sent to Elastic APM, e.g. remove sensitive data. Configure a list of wildcard patterns of field names which should be sanitized. These apply for example to HTTP headers and application/x-www-form-urlencoded data.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.SecretToken
member.summary: A secret token to ensure that only your agents can send data to your APM server. Both agents and APM server have to be configured with the same secret token.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.ServerCert
member.summary: The path to the PEM-encoded certificate used by APM server. This can be used when using a certificate signed by a Certificate Authority (CA) that is not in the trust store, such as a self-signed certificate, to perform validation through certificate pinning.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.ServerUrls
member.summary: The URLs for APM server.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.ServerUrl
member.summary: The URL for APM server.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.ServiceName
member.summary: The name of service instrumented by the APM agent. This is used to group all the errors and transactions of the service together, and is the primary filter in the Elastic APM user interface.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.ServiceNodeName
member.summary: A name used to differentiate between nodes in a service. If not set, data aggregations will be done based on a container ID (where valid) or on the reported hostname (automatically discovered).

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.ServiceVersion
member.summary: The version of the service. If deployments are not versioned, it is recommended to set this to the commit identifier of the deployed revision, e.g. the output of git rev-parse HEAD.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.SpanFramesMinDurationInMilliseconds
member.summary: The agent limits stack trace collection to spans with durations equal or longer than the given value 0: Disables stack trace collection for spans completely negative value: stacktrace will be collected for all spans positive value n: stacktrace will be captured for spans with a duration equal or longer than n ms.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.StackTraceLimit
member.summary: The number of stack frames the agent collects. 0: no stacktrace is collected - This also applies to spans no matter what is the value of SpanFramesMinDurationInMilliseconds. negative: all frames must be collected positive number n: top n frames must be collected

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.TransactionIgnoreUrls
member.summary: A list of patterns to match HTTP requests to ignore. An incoming HTTP request whose request line matches any of the patterns will not be reported as a transaction.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.TransactionMaxSpans
member.summary:
The number of spans that are recorded per transaction.
0: no spans will be collected.
-1: all spans will be collected.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Config.IConfigurationReader.TransactionSampleRate
member.summary: The sample rate for transactions. By default, the agent will sample every transaction (e.g. a request to your service). To reduce overhead and storage requirements, the sample rate can be set to a value between 0.0 and 1.0. The agent still records the overall time and result for unsampled transactions, but no context information, labels, or spans are recorded.

member.name: T:Elastic.Apm.Helpers.Assertion
member.summary: Assertion.IfEnabled?.That(...) is a replacement for System.Diagnostics.Contracts.Contract.Assert for agent's internal use - for us to catch bugs in agent's code. member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Logging.LogLevel.Trace
member.summary: Logs that contain the most detailed messages. These messages may contain sensitive application data. These messages are disabled by default and should never be enabled in a production environment.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Logging.LogLevel.Debug
member.summary: Logs that are used for interactive investigation during development. These logs should primarily contain information useful for debugging and have no long-term value.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Logging.LogLevel.Information
member.summary: Logs that track the general flow of the application. These logs should have long-term value.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Logging.LogLevel.Warning
member.summary: Logs that highlight an abnormal or unexpected event in the application flow, but do not otherwise cause the application execution to stop.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Logging.LogLevel.Error
member.summary: Logs that highlight when the current flow of execution is stopped due to a failure. These should indicate a failure in the current activity, not an application-wide failure.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Logging.LogLevel.Critical
member.summary: Logs that describe an unrecoverable application or system crash, or a catastrophic failure that requires immediate attention.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Logging.LogLevel.None
member.summary: Not used for writing log messages. Specifies that a logging category should not write any messages.

member.summary: Indicates if metrics were already collected - or there was an attempt to collect them. Until this property is false, metrics from the implementor won't be collected. This property exists to cover cases when the metric collection happens in the background (e.g. collecting GC metrics through EventListener) and values are not captured directly in the method. If metrics are captured on the fly in just set this to true during initialization.

member.name: T:Elastic.Apm.Metrics.MetricsCollector
member.summary: Iterates through a list of and sends the values through an instance. It collects the metrics on an interval read from the which is passed to the constructor. In case reading a value from an fails it retries times, after that it prints a log and won't retry anymore. This is to avoid endlessly trying to read values without success.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Model.Span._outcome
member.summary: In general if there is an error on the span, the outcome will be , otherwise it'll be . There are some exceptions to this (see spec: https://github.com/elastic/apm/blob/master/specs/agents/tracing-spans.md#span-outcome) when it can be . member.name: E:Elastic.Apm.Model.Span.Ended
member.summary: When the transaction has ended and before being queued to send to APM server

members.member:
Creates a new transaction
The logger which logs debug information during the transaction creation process The name of the transaction The type of the transaction The sampler implementation which makes the sampling decision Distributed tracing data, in case this transaction is part of a distributed trace The IPayloadSender implementation which will record this transaction The current configuration snapshot which contains the up-do-date config setting values
The ExecutionSegmentsContainer which makes sure this transaction flows Component to fetch info about APM Server (e.g. APM Server version)
If set the transaction will ignore Activity.Current and it's trace id, otherwise the agent will try to keep ids in-sync across async work-flows

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Model.Transaction._activity
member.summary: The agent also starts an Activity when a transaction is started and stops it when the transaction ends. The TraceId of this activity is always the same as the TraceId of the transaction. With this, in case Activity.Current is null, the agent will set it and when the next Activity gets created it'll have this activity as its parent and the TraceId will flow to all Activity instances.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Model.Transaction.ConfigSnapshot
member.summary: Holds configuration snapshot (which is immutable) that was current when this transaction started. We would like transaction data to be consistent and not to be affected by possible changes in agent's configuration between the start and the end of the transaction. That is why the way all the data is collected for the transaction and its spans is controlled by this configuration snapshot.

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Model.Transaction.HasCustomName

member.name: P:Elastic.Apm.Model.Transaction.Outcome
member.summary: The outcome of the transaction: success, failure, or unknown. This is similar to 'result', but has a limited set of permitted values describing the success or failure of the transaction from the service's perspective. This field can be used for calculating error rates for incoming requests.

member.name: F:Elastic.Apm.Model.Transaction._outcome
member.summary: In general if there is an error on the span, the outcome will be , otherwise it'll be . There are some exceptions to this (see spec: https://github.com/elastic/apm/blob/master/specs/agents/tracing-spans.md#span-outcome) when it can be . Use to check if it was specifically set to , or if it's just the default value.

member.name: M:Elastic.Apm.Report.PayloadSenderV2.TryAwaitOrTimeout(System.Threading.Tasks.Task,System.TimeSpan,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: It's recommended to use this method (or another TryAwaitOrTimeout or AwaitOrTimeout method) instead of just Task.WhenAny(taskToAwait, Task.Delay(timeout)) because this method cancels the timer for timeout while Task.Delay(timeout). If the number of zombie timer jobs starts becoming significant, performance could suffer. For more detailed explanation see https://devblogs.microsoft.com/pfxteam/crafting-a-task-timeoutafter-method/

member.name: T:Elastic.Apm.Sampler
member.summary: A sampler is responsible for determining whether a transaction should be sampled. In contrast to other tracing systems, in Elastic APM, non-sampled transactions do get reported to the APM server. However, to keep the size at a minimum, the reported transaction only contains the transaction name, the duration and the id. Also, spans of non-sampled transactions are not reported. This implementation samples based on a sampling probability (AKA sampling rate) between 0.0 and 1.0. A sampling rate of 0.5 means that 50% of all transactions should be sampled.

member.name: M:Elastic.Apm.Sampler.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a new Sampler
member.param: Value of the rate - must be between 0 and 1 (including both)
member.exception: Thrown when rate is not between 0 and 1 (including both)
member.returns: The same value as the given rate

member.name: M:Elastic.Apm.Sampler.RoundToPrecision(System.Double)
member.summary: Rounds the sampling rate half away from zero to 4 decimal places so that the maximum precision of the sampling rate is `0.0001` (0.01%). Values greater than 0 but less than 0.0001 are rounded to 0.0001
member.param: The rate
member.returns: The rounded rate

member.name: M:Elastic.Apm.Sampler.DecideIfToSample(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Decides if to sample or not based on the given randomBytes.
member.param: Should contain at least 8 random bytes.
member.exception: When length of randomBytes is less than 8.
member.returns: True if and only if the decision is to sample
